data.title: Hollywood’s Notable Deaths of 2012
data.meta_description: THR pays tribute to Hollywood figures who died this year.
data.text:
Jack Klugman

Jack Klugman, whose performance as the slovenly New York sportswriter Oscar Madison in the hit ABC series The Odd Couple won him two Emmys and made him a disheveled household name, died Dec. 24. He was 90.

Charles Durning

Charles Durning, the real-life war hero and dependable character actor who appeared in The Sting, Tootsie and most recently as Denis Leary's father on the firefighter drama Rescue Me, died Dec. 24 in his New York City home. He was 89.

Sylvia Kristel

Actress Sylvia Kristel, the Dutch star of the hit 1970s erotic movie Emmanuelle, died Oct. 17 of cancer at age 60. Kristel, a model who turned to acting in the 1970s, had her breakthrough in the 1974 erotic tale directed by Frenchman Just Jaeckin, about the sexual adventures of a man and his beautiful young wife (Kristel) in Thailand. She went on to star in several sequels to Emmanuelle, as well as in Hollywood movies including Private Lessons in 1981.

Alex Karras

Alex Karras, a menacing defensive lineman in college and the NFL who showed a deft comedic touch in films including Blazing Saddles, the 1980s family sitcom Webster and as a commentator on Monday Night Football games, died Oct. 10. He was 77.

Michael Clarke Duncan

Oscar nominee Michael Clarke Duncan, best known for his role in The Green Mile, died Sept. 3 at age 54. The actor was hospitalized July 13 for a myocardial infarction, which his rep said he never fully recovered from. Duncan's fiance, Omarosa Manigault, was with him in the hospital shortly before his death. The actor most recently co-starred with Geoff Stults in Fox's Bones spinoff The Finder.

Neil Armstrong

Neil Armstrong, the first man to walk on the moon, died in August at the age of 82. A shy hero who made history in 1969 and avoided the spotlight afterward, the news of Armstrong's death was broken by NBC News; reporter Jay Barbree was alerted by former astronaut Tom Stafford, who was called by Armstrong's wife. Armstrong is said to have died of complications from heart surgery that took place three weeks ago.

Tony Scott

Director Tony Scott, the action auteur behind such films as Top Gun and Crimson Tide, died on Aug. 19 after jumping off a bridge in what authorities are calling an apparent suicide. He was 68.

PHOTOS: Tony Scott's Films: From 'Top Gun' to 'Unstoppable'

Helen Gurley Brown

Helen Gurley Brown, the legendary editor of Cosmopolitan magazine, died at the age of 90.

She was the wife of the late Hollywood producer David Brown, whose films included Jaws, The Sting, Cocoon, Driving Miss Daisy and The Verdict.

Brown's 1962 bestselling book, Sex and the Single Girl, was an opening act for her more-than-30-year leadership of Cosmopolitan.

Sherman Hemsley

After making a name for himself on "All in The Family," Hemsley starred for 11 years in the hit spin-off, "The Jeffersons." He was 74 years old.

Frank Pierson

Frank Pierson, who won an Academy Award for best original screenplay for Dog Day Afternoon and who was nominated for two Oscars, died at 87. He also served as president of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Science from 2001-05.

Ernest Borgnine

Ernest Borgnine, who made a career out of playing working stiffs and the heavy through a sturdy six decades of work in films, television and Broadway, died Sunday, July 8, at age 95. Borgnine won the best actor in Oscar in 1955 for his sensitive portrayal of the simple, love-starved butcher in the best-picture winner Marty and was nominated for an Emmy for playing the carefree and conniving Quinton McHale in the hit ABC series McHale’s Navy, which aired from 1962-66.

Celeste Holm

Celeste Holm, an Oscar winner for the landmark drama Gentleman's Agreement who played Bette Davis' best friend in All About Eve and the girl who can't say no in Broadway sensation Oklahoma!, died Sunday, July 15, in New York. She was 95.

Andy Griffith

Andy Griffith, who parlayed his folksy North Carolina country charm into a five-decade show business career highlighted by his popular turns as the single-father sheriff in his eponymous 1960s sitcom and the legal show Matlock, died at 86 on July 3.

Nora Ephron

Nora Ephron died June 26 at age 71 after a battle with leukemia. The celebrated writer-director is best known for penning the screenplay for When Harry Met Sally (1989) and then writing and directing Sleepless in Seattle (1989) and You've Got Mail (1998). Most recently, she directed 2009's Julie & Julia, which starred her frequent collaborator Meryl Streep as Julia Child.

Tom Davis

Tom Davis, a comedy writer who teamed with future U.S. senator Al Franken to create scores of memorable sketches for Saturday Night Live — "The Coneheads," "The Continental" and Dan Aykroyd as Julia Child among them — died July 19 of metastatic tonsil cancer at his home in Hudson, N.Y. He was 59.

STORY: Tom Davis, Writing Partner of Al Franken on 'Saturday Night Live,' Dies at 59

LeRoy Nieman

Painter and sketch artist LeRoy Neiman, best known for evoking the kinetic energy of the world's biggest sporting and leisure events with bright quick strokes, died on June 20. He was 91.

Neiman was the official painter of five Olympiads and was a contributing artist at Playboy magazine for many years. His longtime publicist, Gail Parenteau, confirmed his death at a Manhattan hospital but didn't disclose the cause.

Rodney King

Rodney King, who was at the forefront of a police brutality trial after he was videotaped being viciously beaten in 1991, was found dead on June 17. He was 47.

King was found by his fiance, Cynthia Kelley, at the bottom of the swimming pool in his home early Sunday morning in Rialto, Calif.

Ray Bradbury

Ray Bradbury, who authored the novel Fahrenheit 451 and was revered for his science fiction and fantasy writings, died June 5 in Los Angeles. He was 91.

A writer of immense energy and creative abilities, Bradbury was prolific: More than 500 of his works — novels, plays, screenplays, TV scripts, verse — were published or performed. Bradbury's best-regarded and popular books, in addition to Fahrenheit 451, were The Martian Chronicles, The Illustrated Man and Something Wicked This Way Comes.

Robin Gibb

Robin Gibb, who with the Bee Gees was part of one of the top-grossing music acts of all time, died May 20. Gibb's clear vibrato lead was a hallmark of the group’s earliest songs. The singer-songwriter had been battling cancer for more than a year. He was 62.

STORY: Robin Gibb of The Bee Gees Dies at 62

Donna Summer

Donna Summer, the influential “Queen of Disco” who helped define the ’70s dance genre with such hits as “Love to Love You Baby,” “I Feel Love,” “Hot Stuff” and “Bad Girls,” died Thursday of cancer at her home in Key West, Fla., on May 17. She was 63.

STORY: Donna Summer Dies: Disco Queen Dominated Pop Charts in Late 1970s

PHOTOS: Donna Summer's Life and Career in Pictures

Adam Yauch

The founding member of The Beastie Boys, songwriter, director and film distributor behind Oscilloscope died on May 4 after a three-year battle with cancer. Often referred to as MCA, he was best known for his work with the iconic hip hop group that started in 1979 as a punk act. He later segued into film, distribution such features as Dark Days and Exit Through the Gift Shop. Yauch was also an instrumental force in the movement to free Tibet, launching the Tibetan Freedom Concerts of the late '90s. He is survived by wife Dechen Wengdu and their daughter Losel.

STORY: Adam Yauch, Beastie Boys' MCA, Dies at 47

Maurice Sendak

The children's book author and illustrator who's responsible for such famous titles as Where the Wild Things Are and In the Night Kitchen, died on May at the age of 83. He suffered a stroke four days prior.

STORY: Maurice Sendak Dies at 83-Years Old

Dick Clark

Producer, host and "America's youngest teenager" Dick Clark suffered a massive heart attack following an inpatient procedure in Los Angeles on April 18. He was 83. Clark was best known for hosting and creating American Bandstand and New Year's Rockin' Eve — the latter of which he hosted until he suffered a stroke in 2004, handing over the reigns to Ryan Seacrest and only appearing for a few moments during the annual broadcast to kiss his wife Kari Wigton at midnight.

STORY: Dick Clark Dead of Heart Attack at 82

Mike Wallace

Veteran journalist Mike Wallace died peacefully, surrounded by family in New Canaan, Conn., on April 7. He was 93. Wallace was the first correspondent hired by CBS' 60 Minutes and was instrumental in making the program an institution. He interviewed world leaders and important thinkers, and was known for a district attorney-style interviewing style that could make subjects squirm.

STORY: CBS News Legend Mike Wallace Dead at 93

Whitney Houston

Grammy-award winning singer Whitney Houston died on Saturday, February 11, 2012. The powerhouse singer, who had struggled with substance abuse throughout her career, was found dead at the Beverly Hilton at the age of 48.

Etta James

Etta James, the sassy R&B and blues singer whose lush 1961 rendition of the ballad “At Last” has become a slow-dance staple at wedding celebrations everywhere, died Friday, Jan. 20 at Riverside Community Hospital. She was 73.

STORY: Legendary R&B Singer Etta James Dies at 73

Bob Anderson

Bob Anderson, an Olympic fencer, film swordsman, fight director and stunt performer passed away at 89 in his native United Kingdom on Jan. 1. Working with famous players such as Errol Flynn and Antonio Banderas, Anderson's most famous scenes were done nearly anonymously in the Star Wars franchise. He dueled with light sabers in both The Empire Strikes Back and Return of the Jedi.

STORY: Darth Vadar Swordsman Bob Anderson Dies at 89

Sarah Burke

X-Games veteran and daredevil Canadian ski pro Sarah Burke died Thursday, Jan. 19, after a Jan. 11 crash during a training run left her comatose.

Though she successfully underwent surgery to fix a torn artery that caused bleeding between her brain and skull, doctors said the lack of oxygen to her brain in the immediate wake of the accident caused irreparable damage.

STORY: Olympic Hopeful Sarah Burke Dies at 29

James Farentino

Actor James Farentino, who appeared in dozens of movies and television shows, died Tuesday, Jan. 24 in a Los Angeles hospital, according to a family spokesman. He was 73.

Farentino starred alongside Kirk Douglas and Martin Sheen in the 1980 science fiction film The Final Countdown. Farentino also starred opposite Patty Duke in 1969’s Me, Natalie. In 1967, he won a “Most Promising Newcomer” Golden Globe for his performance in the comedy The Pad and How to Use It.

STORY: James Farentino Dies at 73

Leslie Carter

Nick and Aaron Carter’s sister, Leslie Carter, died Tuesday, Jan. 31 at the age of 25. Leslie was signed to DreamWorks Records the late '90s. She had a song featured on the Shrek soundtrack (titled "Like Wow!"), but her debut album was never released by the label.

STORY: Nick and Aaron Carter's Sister Leslie Dies at 25

Zalman King

Zalman King, who directed 1990’s Wild Orchid and produced 1986’s 9 ½ Weeks, died Feb. 3. He was 69 years old. King’s death was first reported by Charlie Sheen on Facebook, who said, "the world lost a brilliant and noble soul today. My dear friend of 40 years, Zalman King, just lost his battle with cancer. Fought like a recon marine til the bitter end. Say a prayer for his amazing wife Pat and their lovely daughters. Safe travels my friend. C".

STORY: Zalman King, Director and Producer, Dies at 69

Zina Bethune

Zina Bethune, an actress, choreographer and dancer, died in the early morning hours Sunday, Feb. 12 after she apparently left her car along Forest Lawn Drive in Los Angeles to assist an injured animal and was struck by oncoming traffic. Bethune suffered head injuries and died at the scene. She was 66.

STORY: Zina Bethune, Actress and Choreographer, Dies at 66

Bill DeCinces

Bill DeCinces, who spent more than a half-century at Universal Studios, going from a ditch digger to head of the art department to running operations at the company’s famed backlot, died Feb. 10 in Tarzana, Calif., from complications of Parkinson’s disease. He was 84.

STORY: Bill DeCinces, Who Spent a Lifetime at Universal Studios, Dies at 84

Davy Jones

Former Monkees frontman Davy Jones died on Feb. 29 at the age of 66 after suffering a heart attack in Florida. The one-time teen idol and Tony Award nominee continued to perform long after the Monkees’ demise, appearing as recently as Feb. 19 in Oklahoma.

Andrew Breitbart

A new media pioneer, Breitbart, who was helping speerhead a conservative movement in the entertainment industry with his Big Hollywood blog and by helping to organize events that attracted as many as 2,000 Republicans in the film and TV industry, died at 43 on Feb. 29. Perhaps best known as the man who brought down Rep. Anthony Weiner over a scandal involving the congressman's inappropriate tweets, died of natural causes after collapsing in his Brentwood home.

Ralph McQuarrie

Ralph McQuarrie, who created the look of Star Wars charracters including Darth Vader, Chewbacca, R2-D2 and C-3PO, died March 3 at the age of 82. The Academy Award winner was known for bringing George Lucas' "Galaxy Far, Far Away" to life, along with working on Raiders of the Lost Ark, E.T. and Close Encounters of the Third Kind.

Robert Sherman

Songwriter Robert Sherman, who composed "It's a Small World After All" and "Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious," died March 5 in London at the age of 86. Sherman had won two Academy Awards and a Grammy Award during his career. With his brother Richard, they were known as The Sherman Brothers, he received a star on the Walk of Fame in 1976.

Steve Bridges

Actor Steve Bridges, known for his dead-ringer and oftentimes hysterical impressions of presidents George W. Bush, Barack Obama and others, died at the age of 48 on March 3, 2012. Bridges made appearances on Larry King Live and The Tonight Show With Jay Leno, as well as such TV dramas as NCIS, JAG and ER. He also appeared as Bush while standing next to the real Bush at the White House Correspondent’s Dinner during Bush’s presidency.

Vidal Sassoon

Vidal Sassoon, who died May 9 in his Mulholland Drive home, was famous for inventing the '60s architectural "wash and go" haircut, snipping Mia Farrow's locks for Rosemary's Baby and being the first to create hair product lines, salons, schools and global outposts for all of the above. Like Halston did in fashion, Sassoon invented self-branding in the beauty business. He was 84.

STORY: Remembering Legendary Hair Stylist Vidal Sassoon

Kathryn Joosten

The actress, who had battled lung cancer for years, died on June 2 in Los Angeles. She was 72. Joosten was best known for her role as Karen McCluskey on ABC's Desperate Housewives and the president's secretary on The West Wing. Joosten won two Emmy awards for her portrayal of Mrs. McCluskey, the cranky but loveable senior who kept a close eye on her Wisteria Lane neighbors on Desperate Housewives.

STORY: 'Desperate Housewives' Actress Kathryn Joosten Dies at 72

Marvin Hamlisch

Marvin Hamlisch, the prolific composer who won Oscars for The Way We Were and The Sting, died Aug. 7 in Los Angeles. He was 68. Over the course of his career, Hamlisch composed more than 40 film scores including Ordinary People, Sophie's Choice and, most recently, Steven Soderbergh's The Informant! He won three Academy Awards, three Golden Globes, four Emmys, four Grammys and a Tony Award in 1975 for the Broadway musical A Chorus Line, for which he also won the Pulitzer Prize.

Johnny Lewis

Actor Johnny Lewis, known for his roles on Sons of Anarchy and The O.C., as well as dating Katy Perry, died Sept. 26 at the age of 28. An investigation ensued as to whether he killed an elderly woman during an attempted break-in, then fell to his death.
